_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Kinetic Resources USA - Lynchburg Propane Terminal
Executive Summary

1. Environment, Health and Safety (EHS) Policy

Kinetic is committed to protecting the health and safety of all individuals affected by our activities. We are committed to safegarding the envirement and contributing to the well-being of the communities in which we operate.
Kinetic works to continually improve our EHS performance by:
- Integrating EHS best practices into all parts of our business.
- Ensuring compliance with applicable laws, regulations and industry standards.
- Identifing, assessing and managing EHS risk throughout our business.
- Ensuring that each employee, contractor and third party service provider understands their EHS responsibilities, is trained to meet them and is monitored for compliance.
-Establishing EHS objectives and regularily measuring our progress.
- Maintaining Kinetic's committment to open and honest dialog with stakeholders.

2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The function of the Lynchburg Terminal is the wholesale distribution of propane. The propane is normally delivered by rail tank car, stored in nine 30,000 gallon capacity vessels and is distributed by customers trucks.The one substance regulated under the Risk Management Plan (RMP) is propane. 
The quantities of propane stored in each 30,000 gallon vessel is controlled to 90% of their capacity to prevent overpressuring. This proceedure is backed up a system to prevent pressure exceeding 250 psi, preventing structural damage to the vessels and also preventing an uncontrolled release. Based on the aforesaid, the maximum inventory in storage at the site is 9 times 27,000 gallons or 241,000 gallons equivalent to 1,027,112 pounds of propane.

3. Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenarios

The parameters of the offsite consequences analyses for the terminal was based on the requirements set forth in RMP rules (40 CFR 68). The worst case and alternate case radii of effect were determined utiliz

ing RMP*Comp software. The fallowing describes the details:
- Worst case scenerio for Program 3 involves a catastrophic release from one of the 9 - 30,000 gallon tanks in the propane storage area and involves the release of the entire content of the tank (27,000 gallons or 114,124 lbs). It is assumed that the entire quantity is released as a vapour and 10% of the released quantity participating in a vapour cloud explosion. Off-site receptors are affected.
- Alternate release senerio for Program 3 involves a release from one of the propane storage tanks when a truck loading pipe/hose is ruptured releasing 49,000 lbs of propane. It assumes that the entire quantity is released as a vapor  with 10% of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud explosion. Off-site receprors would not be affected.

4. General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specefic Prevention Steps

Kinetic Resources has take steps to comply with accidental release prevention requirements under 40 CFR Part 68 as well we are subject to OSHA Process Safety Management 29 CFR 1910.119. The following briefly describes the elements of Kinetic Resources' release prevention program for the Lynchburg Terminal:
(a) Safety Information
Kinetic maintains written information on chemical hazards, operating proceedures and equipment associated with terminal operations.
(b) Process Hazard Analysis
Kinetic Resources ensures that the hazards associated with terminal operations are identified and controlled. The What If? methodoligy has been used in the process. Identified issues have been addressed. Kinetic Resources will continue to review operations on a regular basis and make improvements as appropriate.
(c) Operating Proceedures
Kinetic Resources has written operating proceedures which cover amoung other things safe operations, emergency shut down, normal shut down and start up. This information is regularily reviewed and accessable to all operators.
(d) Training
Kinetic Resources training

of terminal staff is such to ensure safe operation of the facility and protection of staff, contractors and public. New employees receive basic training in facility operations followed by on-the -job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training is provided as needed.
(e) Mechanical Integrety
The integrety of mechanical operations is ensured through documented maintenance checks on major equipment. Process equipment examined include, among others: pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valves, emergency shut down systems, controls, meters and pumps. Maintenance is carried out by qualified personnel at all times. Any equipment deficiencies are carried out in a safe and timely manner.
(f) Compliance Audits
Kinetic Resources will conduct periodic audits at the terminal to ensure the provisions of the RMP rules are implimented  at least every three years as required under 40 CFR 68.58. Any shortcomming will be corrected in a safe and timely manner.
(g) Incident Investigation
Kinetic Resources investigates any occurance that could have or has resulted in a major release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to incident or potential incident as well as corrective action required to prevent a reoccurance. All reports are retained for a minimum five years.
(h) Employee Participation
A successful RMP is a team effort and the terminal staff are an intrigal part of the team and are encourage to express their views. In addition each terminal employee shall have access to all information created as part of the implimentation of the RMP, in particular, information relating to and resulting from process hazard analysis.
(i) Contractors
Periodically Kinetic Resources hires contractors to do specialized maintenance. Each contractor is evaluated for safe performance of activity to be undertaken and fully familiarized with Kinetics safety requirements before comming on site. Furthermore

all contractors are informed of emergency response proceedures shoul an incident occur.

5 Year Accident History
There has been no reportable accidential releases over the past five years at the terminal.

6. Emergency Action Plan
A written action plan to deal with accidential releases of regulated substances and other incidents is maintained at the terminal. The plan includes mitigating actions, medical treatment, evacuation, notification of responders, affected parties and public. To ensure proper response an emergency response team is always in place and equipment regularily inspected/serviced. The RMP is fully coordinated with the Campbell County LEPC and the local fire department.
KInetic Resources will cotinually monitor the implimentation of its RMP in order to prevent accidental releases of propane  and will update the plan as new circumstances arise or new technoligy becomes available.

7. Conclusion
To our knowledge, Kinetic Resources has taken all steps necessary to be fully compliant with EPA and OSHA regulations to continue safe operation of the Lynchburg Terminal. The information submitted herin updates previous information submitted on the facility that Kinetic resources fully embraces. Kinetic Resources  is committed to the safety of all its stakeholders, public and employees and has endevored to put in place measures to fully protect the aforesaid.
